thingsToDo.text: The Farol da Barra Beach is one of the most popular tourist destination in Salvador, Brazil. It offers a panoramic view of the ocean which, in turn, is simply a treat to the eyes. It is simply one of the best destinations to visit for all the tourists who are fond of witnessing nature in all her glory.

thingsToDo.name: Sao Francisco Church and Convent
thingsToDo.text: The Sao Francisco Church and Convent is a great place to visit in Salvador. The architectural style is indeed a unique one and it is simply great to witness. The design in the interior portion of the church is splendid and it never fails to excite the tourists. It is also the richest church in Latin America.

thingsToDo.name: Casa do Rio Vermelho
thingsToDo.text: The Casa do Rio Vermelho is one of the major tourist destinations in Salvador. It is a storehouse of art and is responsible for attracting tourists from all parts of the nation. The jaw-dropping architecture of the Casa do Rio Vermelho is simply a joy to witness. It houses many ancient pictures, arts, and sculptures which can simply take the tourists by surprise.

thingsToDo.name: Santo Antonio da Barra Fort and Nautical Museum
thingsToDo.text: The Santo Antonio da Barra Fort and Nautical Museum reveals the history of Portuguese exploration in the fifteenth and the sixteenth centuries. The museum contains many historical artifacts which were once a part of an ancient ship that sank in the bay around the seventeenth century, only to be found three-hundred years later. There is also a lighthouse named Barra Lighthouse that provides wonderful scenic views of the ocean.

name: Cartagena
description: One of the most gorgeous, romantic, and colorful cities in the world, Cartagena is packed with history, friendly Colombians, and of course, tourists. The walled city is made up of pastel colonial buildings lined with flowers, cobblestone streets, horse carriages, and plenty of restaurants and boutiques to satisfy all of its many visitors.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the Old City
thingsToDo.text: Most tourists will stay in the old city of Cartagena, which includes the neighborhoods of Centro, San Diego, and Getsemani, and you should too. Here you’ll be close to the most historical parts of the city and its picturesque streets, particularly within the walled city (La Ciudad Amurallada), an UNESCO World Heritage Site.

thingsToDo.name: Castillo de San Felipe de Barajas
thingsToDo.text: This might be the most incredible fortress ever built by the Spanish in any of their colonies and it’s a landmark within the city of Cartagena. Construction began in 1639, and it’s never been taken despite numerous attempts to attack the city. There are tunnels within it specifically designed to allow even small sounds to travel well so that any intruders would be detected easily.

thingsToDo.name: Street Food Tour
thingsToDo.text: While you should definitely pick up some cheese-filled arepas and fresh lemonade from the food vendors in the plazas, you might want to sign up for a street food tour to taste even more local dishes. With a guide you’ll get to try things from carts, alleyways, and shops you’d never find on your own.

thingsToDo.name: Visit a Mud Volcano
thingsToDo.text: El Totumo is a small volcano containing thick bubbling mud that you can bathe in and it’s located just outside of Cartagena. You climb inside the hill-like vat where you’ll float in the mud and even have the option of getting a quick massage.

thingsToDo.name: Islas del Rosario
thingsToDo.text: A beautiful day trip while in Cartagena, the Islas del Rosario are 27 islands located in the crystal clear Caribbean waters just off the coast of the city. They’re filled with coral reefs that serve as a natural habitat for tons of aqualife, and you can spend a day here boating, swimming, or snorkeling.

name: Bogota
description: Don’t be intimidated by the sprawling, bustling city of Bogotá. Colombia’s capital is truly historic and packed with touristy things to do, but it’s also got a cool, hip, and even chic side to it as well. From its weekly Ciclovía bike route through the streets to its upscale neighborhoods filled with great restaurants, parks, and excellent nightlife, Bogotá is a real cosmopolitan city.

thingsToDo.name: Stroll Through La Candelaria
thingsToDo.text: This is probably the first thing tourists do in Bogotá because La Candelaria the historic center of the city. Follow the cobblestone streets past colorful Spanish colonial buildings and university halls, check out the street art, and pop into a few cathedrals.

thingsToDo.name: The Gold Museum
thingsToDo.text: Bogotá’s Museo del Oro is the most popular (and possibly the most interesting) museum in the city, and it’s home to more than 30,000 pieces of gold. There are three floors filled with artifacts collected from Colombia’s pre-Hispanic cultures, each focusing on a different theme. Learn how these people discovered, mined, and then worked the metals, making jewelry, masks, bowls, offerings, and armor.

thingsToDo.name: Climb Monserrate
thingsToDo.text: Walk the steep steps up the hill (or take the funicular) to this incredible viewpoint of sprawling Bogotá.

thingsToDo.name: Plaza Bolívar
thingsToDo.text: Head to the center of this capital city to see where government business gets done. This sprawling, pigeon-filled plaza is home to Colombia’s Palace of Justice, the Capitol Building, the Cathedral of Bogotá, and the city mayor’s office.

thingsToDo.name: The Salt Cathedral of Zipaquira
thingsToDo.text: One of the most popular day trips from Bogota, the Salt Cathedral is located in the town of Zipaquirá about an hour outside the city. This whole cathedral was carved deep underground in a salt mine, and it contains alcoves for worshipping and beautifully lit crosses.

thingsToDo.name: Take a Bicycle Tour of the City
thingsToDo.text: While it wouldn’t seem like the best thing to do in a big, bustling city, bike tours of Bogota are really popular. They’re also an excellent way to see a few neighborhoods that are rather spread out and some you wouldn’t stop by on your own.

name: Medellin
description: The second city of Colombia, Medelliin has transformed itself perhaps more than any other city in the world. Though its violent, tumultuous past is well-known, today the city is modern, innovative, and just generally lovely. Nicknamed the “City of Eternal Spring” for its nearly perfect weather, you’ll find plenty of parks and plazas where you can enjoy the sunshine with a fresh juice from a street food vendor and a couple of empanadas.

thingsToDo.name: Museo de Antioquia
thingsToDo.text: A former city hall turned museum, this place houses a great collection of works by Fernando Botero. He’s one of Colombia’s most famous artists, and he had a penchant for painting all things chubby. Guides recommend starting on the top floor with his earlier pieces and making your way down to see his evolution as an artist.

thingsToDo.name: Take the Metrocable Up to Parque Arvi
thingsToDo.text: The metro and metrocable system of Medellín has received lots of praise for bringing a city of many different neighborhoods together. You can get all over the city with your metro ticket, and if you want to venture up for great views and fresh air, pay a little more to take the metrocable from Santo Domingo to Parque Arvi.

thingsToDo.name: The Botanical Gardens
thingsToDo.text: A natural oasis in the center of Medellin, they city’s botanical gardens contain more than 1,000 species of wildlife and 4,500 flowers. There’s a butterfly garden, a cactus garden, and a huge collection of orchids. Entry is free and you can go explore the area to find critters or just lie on the grass in the sun with a book.

thingsToDo.name: Parque Explora
thingsToDo.text: Everybody loves Parque Explora, even adults and those folks without kids. It’s an interactive science museum combined with South America’s largest freshwater aquarium. There are over 300 interactive exhibits housed in the building’s four red cubes, plus a planetarium, 3D auditorium, and a television studio.

thingsToDo.name: Casa de la Memoria
thingsToDo.text: This museum is both upsetting, enlightening, and informative, and it’s the place to go if you want more insight on Colombia’s dramatic and violent history. From drug cartels and gangs to a terrible civil war, Casa de la Memoria aims to amplify the voices of victims and preserve their history so that we might learn more about it and avoid these pitfalls in the future.

thingsToDo.name: Parque Lleras
thingsToDo.text: Poblado is one of the biggest hotspots for nightlife in Medellin, and for locals and tourists alike, Parque Lleras is often the place where you start out the night. It’s just a little park filled with trees where you’ll find vendors selling art by day and crowds of folks drinking by night. The park is surrounded by bars, restaurants, and clubs, plus it’s close to many of the hostels in the area, so there’s always young people around.

name: Santiago
description: Santiago de Chile, more commonly known as just Santiago, was founded by the Spanish in 1541, and has served as Chile’s capital since the colonial days. It’s a bustling city of more than six million people, but you’ll still find traces of its heritage in the colonial and 19th century neoclassical buildings.

thingsToDo.name: La Moneda
thingsToDo.text: La Moneda, also known “Coin Palace” because it used to be a mint, is where the president of Chile has his offices. Several other key government officials also have offices in the neoclassical structure that takes up a whole block in downtown Santiago.

thingsToDo.name: Gran Torre Santiago
thingsToDo.text: The Gran Torre Santiago towers over Santiago and is so high it can be seen from just about anywhere in the city. At 64 stories high, it is the largest skyscraper in Latin America and the highest occupied floor in the Southern Hemisphere. It’s 300 meters (984 feet) high and has six basements.

thingsToDo.name: Cerro Santa Lucia
thingsToDo.text: Cerro Santa Lucia is a hill in central Santiago that represents the remains of a 15-million-year-old volcano. The hill was originally called Huelen but was renamed in 1543 in honor of Santa Lucia when the Spanish conquistadors took the hill. Over the centuries it’s been home to a fort or two, and many dissidents, who either weren’t Roman Catholic or other or others considered unworthy. The hill was remodeled in the 19th century. Today you’ll find a park, statuary, fountains and a castle that has been remodeled into an events center. You’ll also find some great views of Santiago.

thingsToDo.name: Santiago Metropolitan Cathedral
thingsToDo.text: Where earlier cathedrals in Santiago have been destroyed by earthquakes, the Santiago Metropolitan Cathedral has stood on the Plaza de Armas for more than 260 years. Construction first began in 1748 and the cathedral has dominated the square ever since. The stone neoclassical cathedral is considered one of the best examples of religious architecture in South America.

thingsToDo.name: Cerro San Cristobal
thingsToDo.text: Cerro San Cristobal is a hill in northern Santiago that rises over the city, providing some pretty great views. Spanish conquistadors named it for Saint Christopher. At the top you’ll find an observatory and a statue of the Virgin Mary, part of a sanctuary dedicated to the Immaculate Conception. Pope John Paul II blessed the Santiago at a small chapel at the sanctuary; there’s also an amphitheater where masses are held. Cerro San Cristobal also is home to Santiago’s biggest park, Santiago Metropolitan Park; the Chilean national zoo; a Japanese garden and two swimming pools.

name: Easter Island
description: Easter Island is famous for its mysterious background and the Moai statues that accompany it. A plethora of theories surround the origins and construction of these giant, monolithic stone statues, but the truth is that they are the legacy left behind by the Rapa Nui civilization that once inhabited the island.

thingsToDo.name: See The Moais at Rano Raraku National Park
thingsToDo.text: This is the main attraction on Easter Island and the one place you shouldn’t miss. This was the main moai quarry and the place where you’ll see them in all their glory and in all stages of production. In fact, about half of the moai of Easter Island are located in this national park. The Moai are monolithic human statues carved between 1,250 and 1500 AD and are considered to be the “living faces” of deified ancestors. They look inland towards the clan that created them as a sign of protection.

thingsToDo.name: Watch The Sunrise From Tongariki
thingsToDo.text: Here you’ll see its 15 moai statues stand next to each other on an Ahu (ceremonial platform) facing inland as you see the orange sun rise right behind them, creating a shadowy silhouette out of the statues.

thingsToDo.name: Relax at Anakena Beach
thingsToDo.text: Anakena is one of the best beaches on the island, and it is easily accessible. It is a small beach, but that doesn’t matter since there aren’t a lot of people on Easter Island.

thingsToDo.name: See The Ancient Petroglyphs At Papa Vaka
thingsToDo.text: While not a vast legacy, there are still traces of Rapa Nui petroglyphs all around the island, with some of the most important ones found in Papa Vaka, Ana Kai Tangata, and Orongo. These petroglyphs often depict several marine scenes that include fishing, the use of canoes, and various marine animals. Part of the daily life of the Rapa Nui.

thingsToDo.name: Hike To The Top Of Terevaka
thingsToDo.text: Easter Island doesn’t have mountains, they are more like pronounced volcanic hills. Still, it is fun to hike these volcanoes, even if the highest one, Terevaka Volcano, is only 507 meters above sea level. Being the highest point on the island, from there you can get a perfect 360-degree view of all Easter Island.

name: Cairo
description: Headlined by the infamous World Wonder, the architectural marvel that is the Great Pyramids of Giza, Cairo is one of the most fascinating cities in the world. It’s a city of contrasts, where old and new stand side by side, where alive and deceased share land (in the so-called City of the Dead), and where luxurious hotels stand alongside cramped (yet vibrant) souks.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the massive Cairo Citadel
thingsToDo.text: Built in 1176, the Cairo Citadel has a coveted claim to fame as the largest medieval fortress in the world. Following a diverse history of medieval warfare, the stone fortress, now open to visitors, houses four main mosques — the beautiful more modern Mosque of Muhammad Ali, otherwise known as the Alabaster Mosque, the 14th-century Al-Nasir Muhammad Mosque, the Ottoman-style Mosque of Sulayman Pasha, and the lesser-known Mosque of al-‘Azab.

thingsToDo.name: Visit a world wonder — the Giza Pyramids
thingsToDo.text: Standing at a peak of 138 meters tall, no other site in Egypt draws the masses quite like Giza’s Pyramids — the only remaining Wonder of the Ancient World. These three colossal structures (the Great Pyramid of Khufu, Khafre’s Pyramid and Menkaure) have attracted millions of annual visitors since their discovery. They are evidence of the incredible skill and innovation that went into ancient engineering.

thingsToDo.name: Snap a selfie with the Great Sphinx of Giza
thingsToDo.text: Within walking distance of the infamous pyramids (and therefore often combined into the same tour), the 4,500-year-old Sphinx of Giza is another ancient wonder worthy of postcards and millions of travel selfies

thingsToDo.name: Get lost in the Egyptian Museum
thingsToDo.text: An unmissable attraction for history and archeology buffs alike, this downtown Cairo attraction is just next to the Nile. It boasts the world’s largest and most comprehensive collection of Pharaonic history.

name: Luxor
description: Luxor is one of the most ancient cities in Egypt. For many thousands of years, this southern region of the country was home to the most famous Kings and Queens in Egyptian history.

thingsToDo.name: Go to the Luxor Museum
thingsToDo.text: Start your journey to Luxor with a trip to the Luxor Museum, where you’ll be able to learn all about the region’s long and ancient history before you start exploring the multitude of archaeological sites.

thingsToDo.name: Contemplate History at the Luxor Temple
thingsToDo.text: Take a quick walk south along the River Nile and you’ll soon arrive at one of the city’s most impressive ancient sites, the Luxor Temple. You’ll quickly realize just why the city is said to be one of the world’s greatest open-air museums, and that’s down to the fact that archaeological sites in Luxor are literally in the city center.

thingsToDo.name: See the Massive Columns at Karnak
thingsToDo.text: If you walk north along the Nile River from the Luxor Museum, then you’ll come to what is perhaps Luxor’s most famous temple complex, Karnak. Visiting Karnak is one of the best things to do in Luxor because this ancient religious site is one of the most important in Egpyt. The Karnak complex is huge and you’ll find a separate museum on site too, the Karnak Open-Air Museum, where you can enjoy a wealth of information and artifacts.

thingsToDo.name: Learn About Mummies at the Mummification Museum
thingsToDo.text: It’s not always high up on lists of the best things to do in Luxor, but while you’re exploring the museums and temple complexes in the center of the city, you’ll want to pop into the fascinating Mummification Museum too.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the Valley of the Kings
thingsToDo.text: The Valley of the Kings is one of the most iconic archaeological sites in Egypt, and it’s a must-visit when you are in Luxor. The Valley of the Kings, while being a dramatic outdoor attraction in its own right, is iconic because this is where Egyptian kings chose to have their lavish tombs and burial chambers built. Many have been opened, including that of Tutankhamun, and it’s in the Valley of the Kings where modern Egyptology really began to be popularised.

thingsToDo.name: Don’t Forget the Valley of the Queens
thingsToDo.text: The Valley of the Queens is the next valley along from the Valley of the Kings, and as the name might suggest, this is where the Ancient Egyptian Queens were buried in their own lavish burial chambers. There hasn’t been as much excavation here as has been done in the Valley of the Kings, but it’s equally as dramatic and just as important. Not quite as many of the tombs and archaeological sites are open to the public though.

name: Hurghada
description: With the crystalline waters of the Red Sea to the east and the sands of Egypt’s vast desert to the west, Hurghada attracts vacationers from across the globe who want to relax on its endless beaches, explore its spectacular dive sites, and take day trips to the historic cities along the Nile River.

thingsToDo.name: Go Diving in the Caves of the Careless Reef
thingsToDo.text: The appeal of this dive site is self-explanatory: it is a technicolour vision of coral forests wriggling with fish – tuna, jacks and even the occasional hammerhead shark. It’s best known – and loved – among divers, for the large population of giant morays lurking in the depths. Two coral towers brushing the water surface delineate the reef, and the chasm between, about 16m (53ft) deep, is your playground.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Abdel-Moneim Riad Mosque
thingsToDo.text: It’s dubbed the Big Mosque by all who know it, and it’s clear why: its impressive architecture stops passersby in their tracks. Its looks are classically and elegantly Islamic: the arches, domes and hallways are laced with delicate carvings, and the minarets can be seen from miles (kilometres) away. Every day, you’ll hear the call to prayer resonating from within the walls, drifting atmospherically over Hurghada – a reminder you’re in amazing Egypt.

thingsToDo.name: Watch the sunset at the Hurghada Marina Boulevard
thingsToDo.text: Evenings in Hurghada inevitably end with a stroll along the Marina Boulevard. Here, multi-million dollar yachts glint in the late light, floating on transparent waters. You’ll be among visitors from all around the world – and everyone is in awe of the setting.

thingsToDo.name: Marvel at sand sculptures at See Sand City
thingsToDo.text: This open-air museum, just outside Hurghada centre, has two distinct concepts. One focus is on historical and mythological art, borne out in ancient sand sculptures that depict various stories and celebrated military leaders among legendary characters. Contrastingly, there’s Wonderland Art, a display of Walt Disney statues and figures from children’s stories.

thingsToDo.name: Learn to windsurf or kitesurf
thingsToDo.text: If you’re the type who can’t idle on holiday, wiggling your toes in the sand, try learning to windsurf or kitesurf for a breath of fresh air. Whichever activity you sign up for, Hurghada is one of the best locations in the world for beginners.

name: Cape Town
description: Trace the legacy of Nelson Mandela and learn about Cape Town’s history of apartheid at Robben Island and the District Six Museum. Bustling Greenmarket Square is known for its buskers and for its selection of African crafts. Taste fresh-caught tuna, try Cape Malay cuisine, or sample African flavors that span the continent at the city’s restaurants.

thingsToDo.name: Reflect on the History of Apartheid
thingsToDo.text: Nelson Mandela was held captive during apartheid at Robben Island. Today, the island has a museum with exhibits on this dark chapter of South African life. Former inmates lead the tours. Visit District Six Museum for more apartheid history.

thingsToDo.name: Swim with the Penguins at Boulders Beach
thingsToDo.text: See the colony of African Penguins at Boulders Beach and maybe go for a swim.

thingsToDo.name: Find African Art and Handicrafts at Greenmarket Square
thingsToDo.text: The bustling stalls of Greenmarket Square offer a range of unique African souvenirs.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront
thingsToDo.text: Restaurants, nightly music, cocktails, and the Two Oceans Aquarium can be found at this bustling shopping destination.

name: Western Cape
description: The Western Cape is known for its rugged coast, incredible wildlife, and rich history. Soar to new heights with a ride to the summit of Table Mountain on the Aerial Cableway, or lace up your hiking boots and trek one of the mountain’s many trails. Journey to Cape Point where you can admire breathtaking views of the Cape of Good Hope and learn about the Cape’s significance to maritime history.

thingsToDo.name: Visit Table Mountain National Park
thingsToDo.text: Enjoy spectacular views from the summit of Table Mountain, which you can access by cable car or by hiking, and then travel to Cape Point at the Cape of Good Hope for stunning views.

thingsToDo.name: Stroll the Kirstenbosch National Botanical Gardens
thingsToDo.text: View indigenous species as you stroll the winding paths of this botanical garden.

thingsToDo.name: Dive with Sharks in Gansbaai
thingsToDo.text: Gansbaai is known as the Great White Capital of the world. See the sharks from the safety of the boat, or if you’re feeling adventurous, dive with the sharks in a cage.

thingsToDo.name: Whales and Dolphins at Tsitsikamma National Park
thingsToDo.text: See dolphins and whales at this national park that boasts diving, snorkeling, kayaking, swimming, sailing, and even bungee jumping opportunities.

name: Unguja
description: Once trodden by sultans and British imperialists, the capital of Stone Town here bursts with coral-stone forts, Persian palaces, and European frontispieces. And then there are the beaches, from seaweed-spattered Kendwa to whiter-than-white Nungwi and its salt-washed bungalows on the shore.

name: Mount Kilimanjaro National Park
description: A reserve that surely needs no introduction, the exotic reaches of the Mount Kilimanjaro National Park have been a symbol of Africa’s rich biodiversity and eye-popping backcountry since they were first inaugurated by the German colonists back in the 1920s. Today, they magnetise backpackers and intrepid walkers, who flock to strap on the hiking boots and scale the summit of Africa’s highest peak.

name: Ruaha National Park
description: Sprawled out over an area almost exactly the size of Wales, the Ruaha National Park has expanded and expanded over the years to become the single largest game reserve in the entire of East Africa. Today, it ranges more than 20,000 square kilometers over baobab forests, gallery woods and acacia-dotted plains. And despite its size, Ruaha’s relative inaccessibility ensures there are no booming crowds of safari-goers here. Instead, the game experience is up-close-and-personal, with cheetahs and leopards and wild dogs all part of the action.

name: Sydney
description: After you’ve visited the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge, spend some time exploring Sydney’s beaches. Snorkel the waters of Coogee Beach, surf the legendary waves of Manly Beach, or sunbathe with the locals and surfers at Bondi Beach. After you’ve gotten your sunshine, visit some of Sydney’s spectacular museums, most notably, the Hyde Park Barracks Museum and the Australian Museum.

thingsToDo.name: Catch a Performance at the Sydney Opera House
thingsToDo.text: Watch a show or book a fascinating backstage tour that will take you behind the curtains.

thingsToDo.name: Visit Mrs. Macquarie’s Chair
thingsToDo.text: For spectacular views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, visit Mrs. Macquarie’s Chair.

thingsToDo.name: City of Museums
thingsToDo.text: Beyond the UNESCO World Heritage Listed Hyde Park Barracks Museum, there’s the Harbourside Museum of Contemporary Art Australia, the Art Gallery of NSW, the Australian National Maritime Museum, the Powerhouse Museum, and the Nicholson Museum, just to name a few.

thingsToDo.name: Learn to Surf or Go for a Snorkel
thingsToDo.text: Sydney is known for its surf culture at Bondi and Manly Beach, but there are also many opportunities to snorkel and sunbathe on the city’s miles of coast.

name: Melbourne
description: Walk through Melbourne’s laneways and narrow streets, and discover the city’s vibrant restaurants, art galleries, and shops. Enjoy the multicultural cuisine, internationally-renowned art, and uniquely Australian culture. Visit the National Gallery of Victoria, where you’ll find local artists displayed alongside renowned masters like René Magritte. Wander the Royal Botanic Gardens in Melbourne and view rare and local plants.

thingsToDo.name: Walk the Royal Botanic Gardens
thingsToDo.text: See rare plants and local species at this 94-acre botanic garden.

thingsToDo.name: Discover Australian Masters at National Gallery of Victoria
thingsToDo.text: From local artists to well-known masters like René Magritte and Claude Monet, the National Gallery of Victoria offers a survey of both Australian and world art.

thingsToDo.name: Get Lost in Melbourne’s Laneways
thingsToDo.text: Both families and adults-only travelers can discover something new in Melbourne’s laneways—narrow passageways open only to pedestrians.

thingsToDo.name: City of Architecture and Memorials
thingsToDo.text: From the Shrine of Remembrance to the Block Arcade, Melbourne offers something for every architecture enthusiast.

name: Brisbane
description: With year-round beautiful weather, spend your vacation outside in Brisbane. At the River Quay Green, find the city’s most renowned restaurants overlooking views of the Brisbane River and enjoy outdoor music in the evenings. Swim at Streets Beach, an artificial beach in the middle of the city. Go kayaking on the river, take a river cruise, or enjoy a picnic in the city’s lush parks. Meet a koala at the Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Queensland Art Gallery
thingsToDo.text: See aboriginal and local Australian art as well as an internationally-renowned collection of Asian and Pacific art.

thingsToDo.name: Take the Ferry
thingsToDo.text: One of the best ways to explore the city is on the free CityHopper ferry that stops at some of the city’s iconic riverfront shopping and restaurant destinations.

thingsToDo.name: Stroll the Botanic Gardens
thingsToDo.text: See views of the city from the Mount Coot-tha lookout, and wander among the rainforest trees at the Brisbane Botanic Garden.

thingsToDo.name: Hug a Koala at the Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary
thingsToDo.text: See Australia’s iconic animal at this sanctuary committed to conservation, education, and rehabilitation of native Australian animals.

thingsToDo.name: Climb or Cross the Story Bridge
thingsToDo.text: Walk across a catwalk high above the city on the Story Bridge Adventure Climb.

name: Port Douglas
description: Outdoor adventures abound in Port Douglas. Hike the Daintree Rainforest and soak in hidden swimming holes surrounded by exotic flora and fauna. Take a cruise or catamaran to the Great Barrier Reef and explore one of the world’s most diverse ecosystems. Stroll Four Mile Beach’s pristine coastline. In Port Douglas, the wilderness is never far from the comforts of indulgent all-inclusive resorts and restaurants serving exquisite cuisine.

thingsToDo.name: Bask on Four Mile Beach
thingsToDo.text: Walk or swim at Four Mile Beach, a pristine beach with no human development.

thingsToDo.name: Snorkel or SCUBA the Great Barrier Reef
thingsToDo.text: The Great Barrier Reef is just a short cruise from Port Douglas’s marina; tours that leave from the marina can take you into the heart of this natural wonder.

thingsToDo.name: Hike the Oldest Rainforest in the World
thingsToDo.text: Daintree Rainforest is home to unique plants, like the King Fern, and animals like the cassowary and crocodile.

thingsToDo.name: Waterfront Art
thingsToDo.text: From waterfront art markets to charming local galleries, Port Douglas brings artisans, indigenous artists, and photographers to its vibrant cultural landscape.

name: Paradise Island
description: Paradise Island is most famous for its Atlantis Resort & Casino, but tucked away from the crowds, amenities, and activities, you’ll also find some hidden gems. Bask on the soft white sand of Cabbage Beach. Walk along the stone terraces of Versailles Gardens, a beautiful, lush landscape of flowers and tropical plants. Here, you can explore the remains of a French monastery built by Augustinian monks.

thingsToDo.name: Island Augustinian Monastery
thingsToDo.text: You wouldn’t expect to find the remains of a French Augustinian monastery in the Bahamas, but one of the highlights of Paradise Island’s Versailles Gardens is a cloister that was imported to the island by William Randolph Hearst. It is known to have spectacular sunset views.

thingsToDo.name: Bask on Cabbage Beach
thingsToDo.text: Snorkel the famously crystal-clear water or lie on the soft white sand.

thingsToDo.name: Get Your Thrills at Aquaventure
thingsToDo.text: Plunge down water slides, relax on a mile-long lazy river, or soak in over 20 swimming areas.

thingsToDo.name: Golf, Spa, and Casino Fun
thingsToDo.text: In addition to being a luxurious resort, Atlantis boasts a championship ocean-front golf course, a spa incorporating ancient healing techniques and European therapies, and a world-class casino.

name: Nassau
description: Nassau is known for beautiful beaches, rich culture, and vibrant history. Be dazzled by the white sands and turquoise waters of Cable Beach. Cross the bridge to Paradise Island and bask on Cabbage Beach. Delve into Nassau’s history with a visit to Fort Charlotte, Fort Fincastle, the Government House, or the Queen’s Staircase. After a day at the beach, explore the Straw Market and then sip some rum at the John Watling’s Distillery.

thingsToDo.name: White-Sands, Turquoise Waters
thingsToDo.text: There’s a beach in Nassau for every mood: Cable Beach is known for its pristine sand and water, Arawak Cay is known for its seafood shacks, and Junkanoo Beach gives you views of the cruise ships.

thingsToDo.name: Step into 18th Century Nassau at Fort Charlotte
thingsToDo.text: A tour guide in period costume will lead you around this 18th century fort, giving you a glimpse into Nassau’s history.

thingsToDo.name: Sip A Bahama Mama at John Watling’s Distillery
thingsToDo.text: Learn how the rum is made and how to make classic Bahamian cocktails.

thingsToDo.name: Golf by the Sea
thingsToDo.text: Tee-off on the Ocean Club’s championship green, boasting spectacular views of the Atlantic and Nassau Harbour, or play on the Royal Blue designed by Jack Nicklaus, with its ocean views and rolling green.

name: South Coast
description: The South Coast of Barbados is home to the island’s capital city, Bridgetown. This UNESCO World Heritage city is known for its historic British colonial buildings, its stunning Parliament Building, and the oldest Jewish synagogue in the Western Hemisphere. Enjoy the duty-free shopping on Swan Street and Broad Street. Snorkel the shipwrecks of Carlisle Bay, and watch for sea turtles.

thingsToDo.name: Snorkel or Dive a Shipwreck
thingsToDo.text: The shipwrecks in Carlisle Bay draw a range of marine animals, from sea turtles, to octopus, eels, and tropical fish.

thingsToDo.name: Shop Tax-Free
thingsToDo.text: Barbados is a tax-free shopping haven; browse Broad Street, where you’ll find jewelers and boutiques; find fashions on Swan Street, or visit the Pelican Craft Centre for local handicrafts.

thingsToDo.name: Take a Walk Through Historic Bridgetown
thingsToDo.text: Bridgetown is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Stroll the historic architecture, visiting the Parliament Building, the Jewish synagogue, St. Mary’s Church, and the Chamberlain Bridge.

name: West Coast
description: Whether you’re looking for world-class waves, diving or snorkeling adventures, or want to sit back, relax, and sip rum on a white-sand beach, the West Coast of Barbados has it all. Hidden surf spots can be found all along Barbados’ West Coast. Bathsheba Beach is known for its rock formations. Snorkel in the emerald blue water of Brandons Beach and look for sea turtles, or make your way north to Mullins Beach and sip a drink under an umbrella.

thingsToDo.name: Relax at Mullins Beach
thingsToDo.text: Get a tan on the soft white sand or go for a swim in the clear blue water of Mullins Beach.

thingsToDo.name: Surf Barbados
thingsToDo.text: Barbados is known for its surfing, and Bathsheba is a great beach where you can learn to catch your first wave.

thingsToDo.name: Snorkel or Dive the West Coast
thingsToDo.text: Batts Rock is a West Coast Beach known to be frequented by sea turtles.

thingsToDo.name: Get a Massage
thingsToDo.text: The West Coast of Barbados offers beachfront spas where you can enjoy a massage while listening to the sound of the waves.

name: Old San Juan
description: Old San Juan has no beaches, no resort hotels, and not a whole lot of natural beauty—yet it's still one of the best places to visit in Puerto Rico. For all that it lacks, Old San Juan has an incredible 500 years of history, beautiful colonial architecture liberally splashed with tropical colors and timeless magic that makes it one of the most enchanting destinations in the Caribbean. You could spend many happy hours just walking around the walled city.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Forts
thingsToDo.text: Perhaps nothing captures the history of Puerto Rico more than Old San Juan's massive fortresses. El Morro and Castillo de San Cristobal are among the most visited attractions on the island for a good reason. Their cannons, ramparts, and layered defenses have guarded the walled city for centuries. Even the governor's mansion, La Fortaleza, is called 'The Fortress' because it was one of the settlement's early defensive structures.

thingsToDo.name: Dine Out on Fortaleza Street
thingsToDo.text: Dining in Puerto Rico is usually a rewarding experience, whether you're after local classics, gourmet international cuisine, or a delightfully inventive fusion of the Caribbean and global flavors. In Old San Juan, Fortaleza Street has carved out a reputation as a Restaurant Row that includes some of the best restaurants in town. In fact, South Fortaleza, or 'SoFo,' as it's known, even has its own biannual culinary festival.

thingsToDo.name: Take a Sunset Stroll Along Paseo La Princesa
thingsToDo.text: Paseo La Princesa is a broad promenade that stretches from near the docks at the foot of the city and leads to the lovely Raíces Fountain. On weekends, you're likely to find all kinds of stalls lining the road, and maybe even a free cultural performance to enjoy. Paseo La Princesa hugs the old perimeter wall of the city, and beyond the fountain continues around Old San Juan to the San Juan Gate, the only remaining of five original entry points into the old town.

thingsToDo.name: Go Salsa Dancing
thingsToDo.text: Salsa dancing and Puerto Rico go hand in hand, but surprisingly, the island isn't exactly crawling with hallowed halls of salsa. While old favorites like the Nuyorican Café (where Mick Jagger once danced the night away) have closed, newer spots like La Factoría have stepped up to the plate.

thingsToDo.name: Enjoy the City at Night
thingsToDo.text: Take a look at the best lounges, bars, and clubs in San Juan. You'll find several of them in Old San Juan, a city known for its active nightlife. Whether you prefer the chic lounge scene (try Marmalade), grungy and funky bars (El Batey Bar leads that pack) or multi-level discos, Old San Juan doesn't feel so old once the sun goes down.

name: Culebra
description: Culebra is one of the most beautiful places to visit in Puerto Rico because of its tropical island atmosphere and laid-back state of mind. It’s just over 10 square miles in size and an ideal place to relax on the beach, get active in the water, and enjoy a tranquil pace of life. Here are some of the best things to do when you visit Culebra and fun suggestions on how to spend your vacation days here.

thingsToDo.name: Enjoy Flamenco Beach
thingsToDo.text: Flamenco Beach is the most popular places to visit in Culebra and also one of the best beaches in the entire Caribbean. It features lovely sand and water, as well as restrooms, shade trees, picnic tables, and equipment for rent.

thingsToDo.name: Go on a Snorkeling Tour
thingsToDo.text: Snorkeling is a popular activity on Culebra and definitely worth trying while you’re here. Culebra is a common day trip destination from Fajardo for tourists to go snorkeling.

thingsToDo.name: Learn About the Native Plants
thingsToDo.text: There are beautiful plants that naturally flourish on Culebra because of its unique tropical and semi-arid environment.

thingsToDo.name: Check Out Culebrita
thingsToDo.text: Isla Culebrita is a smaller and uninhabited island that accessible from Culebra via water taxi. It is part of the Culebra National Wildlife Refuge and a fun place to visit on a day trip.

name: Punta Cana
description: Punta Cana is known for its white-sand beaches, incredible golf courses, and for its stunning resorts that cater to your every whim. With 10 different courses to choose from, you’ll be sure to find a green that matches your skill. If the beach is more your pace, Playa Bávaro is one of Punta Cana’s most popular beaches for its soft white sand, restaurants, and water activities.

thingsToDo.name: Tee-Off at the Punta Espada Golf Course
thingsToDo.text: This course, designed by Jack Nicklaus, hosts the PGA Champions Tour—when you factor in the ocean wind, this seaside course offers a breathtaking combination of challenge and views.

thingsToDo.name: Swim in the Otherworldly Blue Water of the Hoyo Azul
thingsToDo.text: Hoyo Azul’s dazzling aquamarine water is absolutely breathtaking; Scape Park offers eco-tours of the area as well as cave and cenote tours.

thingsToDo.name: Meet Dominican Republic Wildlife at Manatí Park
thingsToDo.text: See flamingos, parrots, monkeys, dolphins, and 150 other species at Manatí Park.

thingsToDo.name: Snorkel or Dive Punta Cana’s Shipwrecks
thingsToDo.text: Take a snorkel lesson or dive Punta Cana’s shipwrecks teeming with marine life.

name: Puerto Plata
description: Puerto Plata delivers the best of a traditional Dominican Republic port town while boasting the amenities of its all-inclusive beachside resorts. Christopher Columbus set foot on this land, and in good time, Puerto Plata became an important trading port with its own fort. Visit Fortaleza San Felipe, ride the aerial tramway, and explore the Amber Museum.

thingsToDo.name: Visit Fortaleza San Felipe
thingsToDo.text: Step foot in one of the most important colonial forts of the Caribbean; this 16th century fort still has its original cannons and offers stunning views of the Dominican Republic coast.

thingsToDo.name: Ride the Aerial Tram to the Summit of Mount Isabel de Torres
thingsToDo.text: Feel the thrill of riding an aerial tram that will take you to the gardens and statue of Christ that stands on this summit.

thingsToDo.name: Find Amber Treasure
thingsToDo.text: Visit the Amber Museum and admire the collection of amber or browse its shop for authentic amber jewelry.

thingsToDo.name: Get Your Thrills
thingsToDo.text: Take a short drive to Cabarete where the conditions for kitesurfing and windsurfing are ideal, go cliff-jumping at Damajaqua Cascades, or take a leisurely horseback ride through Puerto Plata’s lush landscape.

name: Dubai
description: Be prepared to get dazzled by Dubai. Everything in this second largest Emirate in the U.A.E. is super-sized, super luxurious and state-of-the-art. A cosmopolitan metropolis, Dubai attracts the most seasoned travelers from the world over. You could catch a show at the Dubai Opera, take a 4x4 ride over rippling sand dunes, dine at an upscale restaurant at Jumeriah Beach, ascend the world's tallest building, the Burj al Khalifa or ride a hot-air balloon over the Arabian desert.

thingsToDo.name: Tour traditional Dubai
thingsToDo.text: Get fascinated by Dubai's rich history and tradition as you visit the Al Fahidi Historical Neighborhood, Dubai Creek, and the Gold and Spice Souks.

thingsToDo.name: Dine in style
thingsToDo.text: Sit down to a magical six-course dinner at Al Mahara at the Burj Al Arab Jumeirah, created by a Michelin-starred chef.

thingsToDo.name: Top it off with Burj Khalifa
thingsToDo.text: Head 160 stories up to the observation deck of the tallest building in the world for stunning, panoramic views of magnificent Dubai.

name: Abu Dhabi
description: If it’s culture and adventure you’re seeking, there couldn't be a better time to visit Abu Dhabi. An elegant fusion of sand and sea, UAE’s slick capital graces its visitors with a rich cultural heritage and warm hospitality, skyscrapers and shopping malls, pristine waters and the planet's most spectacular sand dunes. Experience a desert safari. Sail on a catamaran. Enjoy spectacular views from a seaplane. The possibilities are endless.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque
thingsToDo.text: This masterpiece of contemporary Islamic architecture boasts of more than 80 domes, 1000 pillars, 100,000 tons of pure white Greek marble, and the world’s largest chandelier.

thingsToDo.name: Get the thrill of Formula 1
thingsToDo.text: Visit Yas Island for roaring Formula 1 excitement at Abu Dhabi's Grand Prix, the largest sporting event in the Middle East.

thingsToDo.name: Visit Ferrari World
thingsToDo.text: Experience adrenaline-pumping action in the world's largest indoor theme park with 3D & 4D adventures, exhilarating simulation races, and Formula Rossa, the fastest roller coaster in the world.

name: Toronto
description: Toronto is the sum of its multicultural neighborhoods and marketplaces. Taste your way through Greektown, Little Italy, Koreatown, Chinatown, Kensington Market, and the renowned St. Lawrence Market. Ferry to the Toronto Islands for family-friendly fun on the beaches, bike paths, and rides at Centreville Amusement Park, or see the dinosaur bones and Egyptian treasures at the Royal Ontario Museum. The CN Tower is a must-see with dizzying views of the city and lake below.

thingsToDo.name: Catch a Festival
thingsToDo.text: See the Toronto International Film Festival, the largest film festival in the world open to the public; stroll the city streets during Nuit Blanche; catch an indie play at the Toronto Fringe Festival, or explore the city’s restaurants during Summerlicious and Winterlicious.

thingsToDo.name: Eat at 360 Restaurant
thingsToDo.text: Take an elevator to the top of the CN Tower and eat at 360, a revolving restaurant featuring fresh Canadian cuisine.

thingsToDo.name: Browse the Boutiques and Studios of the Distillery District
thingsToDo.text: Discover local artists and artisans housed in beautiful Victorian industrial buildings.

name: Vancouver
description: Vancouver is nestled between the ocean and the North Shore Mountains. Go whale watching, hike a mountain, ski, or discover the city’s multicultural culinary scene. Bike at Stanley Park, passing totem poles, or tee-off at the park’s golf course. For an adrenaline rush, experience the Sky to Sea Gondola over Howe Sound or trek across the Capilano Suspension Bridge. Visit Kitsilano Beach to catch some rays with the locals.

thingsToDo.name: Take a Cruise
thingsToDo.text: Want to cruise to Alaska? Vancouver is one of the leading ports from which to begin your adventure north.

thingsToDo.name: Explore Stanley Park
thingsToDo.text: Rent a bike and cycle the seawall that runs 20 miles along Vancouver’s waterfront. The park boasts family-friendly playgrounds, a water park, and the Vancouver Aquarium. Admire stately cedars, maples, and Douglas fir.

thingsToDo.name: Art and Culture at Granville Island
thingsToDo.text: Find Vancouver’s design studios, galleries, leading cuisine, and vibrant market.

thingsToDo.name: Visit VanDusen Botanical Garden
thingsToDo.text: If you’re visiting Vancouver in the spring, be sure to take the famous Laburnum Walk; the garden boasts year-round blooms.

name: Niagara Falls
description: Three different waterfalls make up Niagara Falls: Horseshoe Falls, the American Falls, and the Bridal Veil Falls. Horseshoe Falls is arguably the most dramatic and is best viewed from the Canadian city of Niagara Falls. The city’s glittering entertainment district boasts a range of attractions, including the Maid of the Mist boat ride, the Journey Behind the Falls, Niagara Skywheel, Skylon Tower, and Niagara Casino.

thingsToDo.name: Ride the Maid of the Mist
thingsToDo.text: You’ll get so close to the falls on this boat ride, you’ll have to wear a poncho. The views are stunning.

thingsToDo.name: Niagara Glen Nature Reserve
thingsToDo.text: Hike through the reserve, weaving through natural boulders and the Niagara Escarpment, enjoying breathtaking views of the rushing Niagara River.

thingsToDo.name: Skylon Tower
thingsToDo.text: There are many ways to experience the falls, but for a truly unique view, ride to the observation deck of the Skylon Tower to see the falls from above.

name: Prague
description: One of Europe’s most fascinating cities, Prague has a skyline of cathedrals, fairy-tale castles and soaring towers. And down below, a vibrant urban center, nestled amidst ancient monuments and bridges, offers a plethora of dining options, bustling markets and jazz clubs. Explore the past and the present with our guided tour for a truly surreal experience.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the Old Town Square
thingsToDo.text: Despite Prague’s lively history of invasions, the Old Town Square has remained relatively untouched since the 10th Century. Swarms of tourists crowd the historical streets, packing out the alfresco restaurants everyday. The square itself is the perfect place to admire the wonderful architecture Prague has to offer and if that isn’t your thing then the various street performers, musicians and merchants that line the streets here will certainly keep you entertained.

thingsToDo.name: Stroll across the Charles Bridge
thingsToDo.text: Whoever said that “the best things in life are free” may well have been referring to the Charles Bridge in Prague. A simple walk across the 14th Century bridge is one of the most enjoyable and memorable experiences of visiting Prague. The bridge was commissioned in 1357 by Charles IV to replace an older bridge that had been washed away by floods. Although completed in 1390, with the striking statues added in the 17th century, the bridge did not take Charles’ name until the 19th century.

thingsToDo.name: Visit Prague Castle
thingsToDo.text: Located in Hradcany (the Castle district), Prague Castle is without a doubt the city’s most popular tourist attraction and it is easy to see why. The breath-taking castle has traditionally been the seat of Czech rulers and is today the official residence of the president.

thingsToDo.name: Drink a world famous beer (or two)
thingsToDo.text: The Czechs claim to have the best beer (pivo) in the world and Prague is a great place to test their claim. The huge choice of bars in the city offer famous Czech lagers such as Budvar and Staropramen alongside craft beers from the top microbreweries in the country. Most Czech beers are light beers, brewed naturally from hand-picked hops.

thingsToDo.name: Immerse yourself in the Prague nightlife
thingsToDo.text: Prague’s nightlife has it all. World renowned for its jazz and classical music, there are many live music venues in Prague that can provide a good evening of entertainment. Take a stroll down the riverside and arrive at JazzDock which draws some of the best local jazz musicians. For serious clubbers, the Cross Club is an industrial nightclub in every sense of the word.

name: Cesky Krumlov
description: A fairy-tale pop-up of a town that crowns a series of bluffs on the edge of the Vltava River south of Ceske Budejovice, Cesky Krumlov is one of the veritable jewels of South Bohemia. Its Old Town bears a well-deserved UNESCO tag for its maze of medieval streets, 13th century relics and layers of architectural history – much of which has remained unspoilt by conflict and war.

thingsToDo.name: Take in the Sights at the Ceský Krumlov Castle
thingsToDo.text: The massive Ceský Krumlov Castle complex – the largest in Eastern Europe – dominates the old town and offers a fascinating look into the lives of the aristocratic rulers of Bohemia through the centuries. Although tracing its roots back to 1240, much of what's seen today was built in the 17th century, including the fine Rosenberg Ballroom, the splendid Chapel of St. George, the Renaissance Hall, and the Royal Apartments.

thingsToDo.name: Explore Art City: Fine Frescoes and the Egon Schiele Art Centrum
thingsToDo.text: A highlight of a visit to Ceský Krumlov is simply walking its many old streets and soaking up the splendid artwork that is everywhere around you. The city is famous for its many frescoes, a tradition that dates back centuries.

thingsToDo.name: Experience Rafting Down the Vltava River
thingsToDo.text: The fairytale town of Cesky Krumlov is perfect to be enjoyed from the water, as you raft down the Vltava River and past stunning architecture. You can hop on a raft just steps from the castle and go downstream towards Ceske Budejovice, another dreamy town with its own magical Old Town. On the way you'll pass by the town of Zlata Koruna and its old monastery and have a chance to stop by waterfront snack stands to grab a bite or a cold drink.

thingsToDo.name: Climb Mount Klet
thingsToDo.text: Located on the outskirts of Ceský Krumlov, the 1,084-meter-high Mount Klet' makes an excellent diversion after all that sightseeing in the historic old city. Getting there is half the fun, and reaching the summit can be done on foot by following the well-marked trails, or aboard a fast chairlift

name: Brno
description: Pulsing with an indelible student energy during term times from its place in the southern depths of the Czech Republic, Brno – the regional capital of South Moravia – belies its local rep as a rather sleepy place with some of the country’s top drum and bass clubs and a booming café culture to rival both Prague and Vienna. There’s also a gorgeous Old Town district to see; the second largest in the country, where the spiked Neo-gothic towers of the Cathedral of St Peter and Paul stand watch over cobbled squares and the eerie tunnels of the Brno Ossuary lurk underground. Spilberk Castle crowns a bluff in the midst of the town too, while Brno Reservoir is a hubbub of recreational activity during the summer, offering boating, swimming and al fresco drinking opportunities aplenty.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Old Town Hall
thingsToDo.text: Here you get an idea of Brno’s enduring sense of fun, as well as a neat view of the city from the roost of the tower. On approach you might notice that one of the turrets on the Town Hall’s decorative facade looks a bit skewed. The story goes that Anton Pilgram, the building’s architect was screwed out of money by Brno’s City Council and his payback was to mess with the design. The other version holds that he was simply too drunk to get it right. The building goes back to the 1200s, and formed part of the city defences during the famous siege by Swedish forces in 1645.

thingsToDo.name: Visit Freedom Square – Namesti Svobody
thingsToDo.text: Freedom Square (Náměstí Svobody in Czech) is one of the main hubs of activity and interest in the city. It’s also among the top things to do in Brno. The triangular square is surrounded by a number of stunning Renaissance and functionalist style buildings. Sure to please any architecture enthusiast!

thingsToDo.name: Visit Zelny trh aka the Cabbage Market
thingsToDo.text: Vegetables, Mozart, hidden underground labyrinths, fabulous vegan ice cream, and Baroque architecture. This and more can be found in Brno’s Zelny trh square.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Capuchin Crypt
thingsToDo.text: The Capuchin Crypt in central Brno is the final resting places of the mummified remains of Capuchin monks. A self-guided tour with an English pamphlet is a good way to kill half an hour, especially on a rainy day.

name: Ostrava
description: Sat just on the northern edge of Moravia, where the Czech Republic gives way to Silesia and the Polish borderlands, Ostrava is a down-to-earth gem of a city that fuses historical beauty and Baroque brilliance in its old town with an interesting mix of Soviet Realism, Russian Brutalism and post-industrial sprawl.

thingsToDo.name: Vitkovice
thingsToDo.text: In case you need proof of Ostrava’s pride in its industrial roots the vast industrial remnants of the Vitkovice metallurgy district have been cherished and transformed into modern attractions. The cavernous gasometer is a concert hall, while the 19th-century blast furnace is part of a tour that includes a 60-metre-high lookout accessed by an industrial elevator. The whole district is on the European cultural heritage list.

thingsToDo.name: Landek Park
thingsToDo.text: It’s fitting that Ostrava should boast the Czech Republic’s premier mining attraction, because people have been making use of the mineral deposits in Landek Park since time immemorial. Landek Park puts you right in the boots of a miner, to experience the good and not so good sides of industrialised mining in Ostrava over the last two centuries.

thingsToDo.name: Miniuni Miniature Park
thingsToDo.text: This is a fun diversion for families with younger children. In a landscaped 1.5-hectare park are some 30 models of famous landmarks from around the world. The Brandenburg Gate, The Eiffel Tower and London’s Houses of Parliament are all here, carefully constructed at a scale of 1:25. A recent update has brought the Wonders of the Ancient World to this corner of the Czech Republic.

thingsToDo.name: Ostravar Brewery
thingsToDo.text: Ostravar, which comes in light beer and light lager varieties (Original and Premium), isn’t a household name outside of upper Moravia, but has a big local market. Beer is of course the Czech Republic’s national drink, and at this 19th-century brewery you’ll be walked through the brewing process, from the brewhouse with its large copper vats, to the cellar where the beer develops its depth.

name: Moravian Karst
description: A land of more than 1,000 caves and grottoes, gorges and canyons, the Moravian Karst sprawls out over a whopping 92 square kilometers just north of the city of Brno. It’s famed for its array of breathtaking geological wonders, going from the sculpted stalactites and colossal stalagmites, underground rivers and sinkholes of the Punkva Caves to the domed chambers and winding corridors of the vast Amaterska system. The place is also home to the great Macocha Gorge – the largest sinkhole canyon of its kind in all of Central Europe that plays host to the bubbling headwaters of the Punkva River. Hiking, caving and biking opportunities abound here, and travelers can also seek out the Josefov blast furnaces and Chateau of Rajec nad Svitavou nearby.

name: Bohemian Paradise
description: The first ever natural reserve in the Czech Republic is an enchanting land of towering hoodoos and canyons, curious chiselled cliffs, cascading gores and rugged hills, all dressed in sweeping dashes of pine forest, crisscrossed by winding hiking trails and dotted with the romantic silhouettes of castles like the precipitous Trosky keep. Visitors touring the region can delve into ancient rock towns that protrude almost organically from the sandstone ridges they stand on, explore dramatic dolomite caverns at Bozkov, see folksy timber architecture between the rustic villages, go lake hopping, kayaking or canyon scaling, enjoy horse riding in the shadow of ancestral chateaux – the list goes on!

name: London
description: Planning a trip across the pond? From finding Abbey Road to catching the changing of the guards at Buckingham Palace, we can help you revel in London’s endless activities. Take exciting tours of iconic landmarks like Westminster Abbey and the Tower Bridge. Then, follow it up by exploring the famous Portobello street market in Notting Hill. The possibilities are endless in this capital city.

thingsToDo.name: See the Buckingham Palace
thingsToDo.text: A trip to London is incomplete without strolling through Green Park to catch a glimpse of Buckingham Palace. The palace has been home to the British Royal Family since 1837. It features 775 rooms and the largest private garden in London.

thingsToDo.name: Take the Thames Cruise
thingsToDo.text: The Thames is the lifeblood of London, bringing industry to the city for centuries. It is England’s longest river, leading into the North Sea at its end. It has been the base for settlements since prehistoric times, and was a strategic importance to the Romans and English Kings, as well as during both World Wars.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the London Eye
thingsToDo.text: A trip to London isn’t complete without a visit to the iconic London Eye. Originally constructed to celebrate the millennium, the Eye is a giant ferris wheel offering gorgeous views across the city. At night, the wheel is lit up in seasonal colors and is the centerpiece of London’s annual New Year’s fireworks display.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the Hyde Park
thingsToDo.text: Hyde Park is possibly the most famous park in London, and it is one of the largest. The park has historical significance, having hosted a number of demonstrations and protests including protests by the Suffragettes.

name: Manchester
description: Manchester is England’s second biggest city, having been settled since 79 AD by the Romans. Manchester is a vibrant urban hotspot with excellent nightlife, arts and culture. The city is surrounded by countryside and the gorgeous Pennine mountains, making it a great base for exploring wilder regions of the country. Manchester has an extensive history and is important in many fields, including music, science and transport.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Manchester Museum
thingsToDo.text: The Manchester Museum is the country’s biggest university museum with a collection of 4,500,000 items from all around the world. The museum is housed within a striking gothic-style building and showcases the best in archaeology and natural history.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the Manchester Art Gallery
thingsToDo.text: Manchester Art Gallery is situated in the city centre, in a building that has stood on this space since 1823. The gallery celebrates local and international work with an extensive collection that spans centuries. Here you will find paintings by artists such as Gainsborough, Turner and Pissarro. The gallery also features collections of crafts, from ceramics to metalwork and home items, as well as clothing and accessories dating from 1600 to the modern day.

thingsToDo.name: See the Old Trafford
thingsToDo.text: For football fans, a visit to Old Trafford football stadium is a must. Home to Manchester United FC since 1910, the stadium is the largest in the country and one of its most iconic. Book a tour for a unique experience through the football grounds, backstage, and into the on-site museum.

thingsToDo.name: Experience Manchester’s Craft Beer
thingsToDo.text: Manchester is well-known for its craft beer scene which has sprung up over the past few years. There are many pubs and bars offering real ale and home-brewed craft beer, and even annual festivals celebrating the city’s beer.

name: Oxford
description: From the glorious Bodleian Library to the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford is jam-packed with fantastic things to see and do. It has incredible architecture, superb art and a storied past dating back to Anglo-Saxon times – here, you can follow in the footsteps of Prime Ministers, poets and, of course, Harry Potter.

thingsToDo.name: Tour the Bodleian Library
thingsToDo.text: The Bodleian is the historic heart of the University of Oxford. It’s the institute’s main research library and one of the oldest in Europe, dating back over 400 years. It sits in Radcliffe Square and houses ancient manuscripts, rare books, printed ephemera and maps.

thingsToDo.name: Smell the roses at the University of Oxford Botanic Garden
thingsToDo.text: The oldest of its kind in England, Oxford’s small botanic garden was founded in 1621 for the study of medicinal plants, and remains a department of the university today. It is run more for research purposes than for display, but it’s in a tranquil and colourful spot beside the River Cherwell.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Oxford University Museum of Natural History
thingsToDo.text: Here, you can see specimens from all over the world, including a 150-year-old Japanese spider crab, a stunning example of neogothic architecture and a meteorite that fell from space 4.5 billion years ago. But it’s the dinosaurs that really draw the crowds. As well as a towering T-Rex skeleton – ‘Stan’, the second most complete ever found – you’ll see pieces of Megalosaurus, which, in 1677, was the first dinosaur ever mentioned in a written text.
